front.title: JSCalendar: Converting from and to iCalendar

abstract.t: This document defines how to convert calendaring information between the JSCalendar and iCalendar data formats. It considers every JSCalendar and iCalendar element registered at IANA at the time of publication. It defines conversion rules for all elements that are common to both formats, as well as how convert arbitrary or unknown JSCalendar and iCalendar elements.

section.name: Notational Conventions
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCPÂ 14 when, and only when, they appear in all capitals, as shown here.
The ABNF definitions in this document use the notations of . ABNF rules not defined in this document either are defined in or .

section.name: Scope and Goals
section.t: This document outlines how to convert calendaring information between the iCalendar and JSCalendar data formats. It describes which elements are common to both, but also highlights where the two formats differ. For each common element, it defines a conversion rule and includes an example of how to convert that element. All iCalendar and JSCalendar elements currently registered at IANA are in scope, but not all of these elements are common to both formats.

For elements that have no counterpart in the other format, it is the goal of this document to define how to preserve them during conversion, but in general it is not the goal to achieve this by defining new standard elements. Instead, this document defines special-purpose properties to preserve arbitrary elements. These conversion-specific properties are defined in Section for iCalendar, and Sections and for JSCalendar. further outlines the discrepancies between the two formats.

section.name: How to Read the Examples
section.t: Later sections contain examples that illustrate how to convert between the iCalendar and JSCalendar data formats. The notation of these examples is such that their main points should be clear to the reader, but their contents can also be parsed for automated testing. The following sections define the notation for such examples.

section.name: iCalendar Examples
section.t: An iCalendar example contains either an extract or a complete representation of iCalendar data. It always represents an iCalendar object, even if the example only depicts non-VCALENDAR components or properties. The following rules apply:

ul.li: An example that only contains iCalendar properties implicitly represents a VEVENT component that is part of a VCALENDAR component.
An example that only contains one or more non-VCALENDAR components implicitly represents a VCALENDAR component that contains them.
An example that only contains a VCALENDAR component but no contained components implicitly represents a VCALENDAR component that contains a VEVENT component.
Implicit components (those without a BEGIN and END, or omitted completely) are assumed to contain all mandatory properties with some value, but the actual value is irrelevant for the example.

section.t: contains three examples, all of which represent the same iCalendar data. In the first example, both the VEVENT component and VCALENDAR component are implicit. In the second example, only the VCALENDAR component and its mandatory properties are implicit. The third example depicts a complete VCALENDAR component, nothing is implicit.

figure.name: Examples for implicit and explicit iCalendar component notation
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VEVENT DTSTAMP:20060102T030405Z DTSTART:20060102T030405Z SUMMARY:hello UID:CC0A494A-6E07-4827-8294-0752DD1ECFA4 END:VEVENT
BEGIN:VCALENDAR PRODID:-//FOO//bar//EN VERSION:2.0 BEGIN:VEVENT DTSTAMP:20060102T030405Z DTSTART:20060102T030405Z SUMMARY:hello UID:CC0A494A-6E07-4827-8294-0752DD1ECFA4 END:VEVENT END:VCALENDAR

section.t: A line containing just the value ... stands for any other properties that might be present in a component but are irrelevant for this example. This includes mandatory properties as described for implicit components. The line ... at the end of the example additionally stands for any END content lines to complete components that started with BEGIN content lines, and any of their missing mandatory properties. illustrates this as an alternative representation for the examples of .

figure.name: Example for additional properties and component ENDs represented by ...

section.t: A line starting with a single space represents the continuation of a folded content line (). illustrates this.

figure.name: Example for a folded content line

section.name: JSCalendar Examples
section.t: A JSCalendar example always represents a Group object, even if the example only depicts one of the Group entries or properties.

JSCalendar objects are depicted either explicitly or implicitly. An explicit JSCalendar object starts and ends with braces. An implicit JSCalendar object omits braces, it only consists of JSON name/value pairs, separated by comma.

An implicit JSCalendar object is assumed to be of type Event, unless it contains the @type property with a different value. It is assumed to contain all mandatory properties with some value; if they are not depicted, their actual value is irrelevant for the main point of the example.

illustrates this with multiple examples, all of which represent the same JSCalendar data. The first example contains an implicit JSCalendar object of type Event. The second example contains an implicit JSCalendar object with a @type property. The third example contains an explicit Event object but the Group object containing it is omitted. The fourth example contains the full Group object, nothing is omitted.

figure.name: Examples for implicit and explicit JSCalendar object notation

section.t: A property with name "..." and value "" stands for additional properties that might be present in a JSCalendar object but are irrelevant for this example, including mandatory properties. The "..." property requires the "@type" property to be set. illustrates this as an alternative representation for the examples of .

figure.name: Example for additional properties represented by ...

section.name: Lossy versus Lossless Conversion
section.t: This document outlines how to convert iCalendar elements to JSCalendar elements, and the other way round. Many of these can be represented by standard elements in both formats, meaning that they are registered in the iCalendar and JSCalendar IANA registries and differ from the special-purpose elements introduced in and . Still, a number of elements in either format have no standard counterpart in the other. When converting between between iCalendar and JSCalendar, implementations MAY choose to only convert elements that have standard element in the target format, or aim to preserve as many elements as possible.
When to choose between lossy and lossless conversion is implementation-specific. For example:

ul.li: For lossy conversion, an implementation that internally stores calendar data in JSCalendar format might only want to convert to a subset of iCalendar elements for iMIP scheduling. In this case, it might not make use any of the conversion-specific iCalendar properties introduced in .

For lossless conversion, an implementation that internally stores calendar data in iCalendar format might want to convert without loss to JSCalendar when updating calendar events with JMAP. For that, it can use the conversion-specific properties defined in .

section.t: All the examples in this document illustrate lossless conversion, if not explicitly stated otherwise in the example.

section.name: iCalendar Objects
section.t: allows for an iCalendar stream to contain one or more iCalendar objects. In contrast, this specification only defines conversion for streams consisting of a single iCalendar object. Converting streams of multiple iCalendar objects is implementation-specific. All following sections of this document use the terms "iCalendar object" and "VCALENDAR component" interchangeably.
The VCALENDAR component converts to a Group object. Its properties convert as follows:
Its components convert as follows:
Other properties or components MAY be converted to the "iCalComponent" property of the Group object.
The order of elements in the "entries" property is implementation-specific, e.g. entries need not be in the same order as their source components in the iCalendar object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the VCALENDAR component:

figure.name: Converting the VCALENDAR component

section.name: Recurring Components
section.t: Components in an iCalendar object generally convert to distinct JSCalendar objects. For example, two VEVENT components with different UID property values in the same iCalendar object convert to two separate Event objects in the Group object's entries. As an exception to this rule, this does not apply to recurrence overrides, defined as follows.

A VEVENT (or VTODO) component is a recurrence override if it has the RECURRENCE-ID property set, and the iCalendar object contains a VEVENT (or VTODO) component that does not have the RECURRENCE-ID but the RRULE property set, and the UID property values of the two components are equal. The component without the RECURRENCE-ID property is in that case referred to as the "main component".
The main component converts to an entry in the Group object's entries property.

The recurrence override converts to the "recurrenceOverrides" property of the converted main component. Its RECURRENCE-ID property value converts to the key in the "recurrenceOverrides" property. The value of the "recurrenceOverrides" property at that key is a PatchObject that transform the converted main component into the converted recurrence override. The recurrenceId and recurrenceIdTimeZone properties MUST NOT be set in the PatchObject.
The following example illustrates how to convert a main component and its recurrence override:

figure.name: Converting VEVENT recurrence overrides
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VCALENDAR BEGIN:VEVENT UID:F4257E1D-5461-4EF6-840F-9DFC653EB559 RRULE:FREQ=DAILY DTSTART;TZID=Europe/Berlin:20240101T140000 ... END:VEVENT BEGIN:VEVENT UID:F4257E1D-5461-4EF6-840F-9DFC653EB559 RECURRENCE-ID;TZID=Europe/Berlin:20240202T140000 DTSTART;TZID=Europe/Berlin:20240202T160000 ... END:VEVENT END:VCALENDAR

section.t: A VEVENT (or VTODO) component is a stand-alone recurrence instance if it has the RECURRENCE-ID property set and the iCalendar object does not contain its related main component. Each stand-alone recurrence instance converts to a distinct Event (or Task) object in the Group object's entries property. The recurrenceId property MUST be set, the "recurrenceIdTimeZone" property MUST be set if not "null".
The following example illustrates how to convert stand-alone recurrence instances:

figure.name: Converting VEVENT recurrence instances
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VCALENDAR BEGIN:VEVENT UID:F4257E1D-5461-4EF6-840F-9DFC653EB559 RECURRENCE-ID;TZID=Europe/Berlin:20240202T140000 DTSTART;TZID=Europe/Berlin:20240202T160000 ... END:VEVENT BEGIN:VEVENT UID:F4257E1D-5461-4EF6-840F-9DFC653EB559 RECURRENCE-ID;TZID=Europe/Berlin:20240103T140000 DTSTART;TZID=Europe/Berlin:20240103T170000 ... END:VEVENT END:VCALENDAR

section.name: JSCalendar Ids
section.t: JSCalendar generally uses JSON objects to represent a collection of same-typed values. The keys are of type Id, the values are JSCalendar object types. If an iCalendar element converts to a value in such a collection, then an implementation needs to choose an identifier as key.

This document defines the new JSID parameter and JSID property, which allow to set a JSCalendar Id value when converting from JSCalendar to iCalendar. If they are set on a property or the component, then its value MUST be used as key when converting that element from iCalendar to JSCalendar. If no such parameter or property is set, then an implementation is free to choose any identifier, as long the following requirements are met:

ul.li: The identifier MUST be a valid Id value.
The identifiers for the exact same iCalendar element MUST stay the same, irrespective of the order in which components, properties and parameters are processed.

section.name: Timezone identifiers
section.t: Converting temporal properties such as DTSTART, DTEND, and RECURRENCE-ID requires to not only determine the date and time of the property value, but also the timezone it references.
If the property value type is DATE or DATE-TIME in FORM #1: DATE WITH LOCAL TIME then the timezone identifier is the JSON null value in JSCalendar.
If the property value type is DATE-TIME in FORM #2: DATE WITH UTC TIME then the timezone identifier is the string "Etc/UTC" in JSCalendar.
If the property value type is DATE-TIME in FORM #3: DATE WITH LOCAL TIME AND TIME ZONE REFERENCE then the timezone identifier is determined by the TZID parameter value:

If the TZID parameter value is equal to a name in the IANA Time Zone Database then the timezone identifier is that verbatim name. Otherwise, how to convert the TZID parameter value is implementation-specific: software libraries such as the International Components for Unicode support converting Microsoft time zone names to IANA time zone identifiers. Alternatively, finding an IANA time zone for which the time zone offset changes match those of the custom time zone over the span of the event or task is typically possible.

section.name: DATE and DATE-TIME
section.t: iCalendar provides the DATE and DATE-TIME value types to distinguish date-only from date-time values. JSCalendar only supports date-time values. A property value of type DATE-TIME converts to either a LocalDateTime or UTCDateTime, depending on the JSCalendar property definition. A DATE value type converts to a LocalDateTime with zero time.

section.name: PARTICIPANT
section.t: The PARTICIPANT component converts to a Participant object. Its properties convert as follows:
Other properties or components MAY be converted to the "iCalComponent" property of the Participant object. This includes mandatory properties such as UID.
The following example illustrates how to convert the PARTICIPANT component:

figure.name: Converting the PARTICIPANT component
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VEVENT BEGIN:PARTICIPANT UID:47AD2E1C-49D4-45DF-BD83-8398ACC7D8E2 DESCRIPTION:A participant END:PARTICIPANT ...

section.name: VALARM
section.t: The VALARM component converts to an Alert object. Its properties convert as follows:

tr.td: Only if ACTION is EMAIL or DISPLAY.

section.t: Other properties or components MAY be converted to the "iCalComponent" property of the Alert object. This includes mandatory properties such as ATTENDEE, DESCRIPTION, or SUMMARY.
The following example illustrates how to convert the VALARM component:

figure.name: Converting the VALARM component
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VEVENT BEGIN:VALARM TRIGGER:-PT30M ACTION:DISPLAY DESCRIPTION:Breakfast meeting END:VALARM ...

section.name: VCONFERENCE
section.t: The VCONFERENCE component converts to a VirtualLocation object. It MUST convert to the same VirtualLocation to which its related CONFERENCE property converts. Its properties convert as follows:
Other properties or components MAY be converted to the "iCalComponent" property of the VirtualLocation object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the VCONFERENCE component:

figure.name: Converting the VCONFERENCE component
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VCONFERENCE URI;VALUE=URI:https://chat.example.com/x?id=123456 STYLED-DESCRIPTION;VALUE=TEXT;FMTTYPE=text/html:Click here to download t he client.. ... END:VCONFERENCE CONFERENCE;VALUE=URI;FEATURE=AUDIO,VIDEO; LABEL=Team meeting:https://chat.example.com/x?id=123456

section.name: VEVENT
section.t: The VEVENT component converts to a Event object. Its properties convert as follows:
Its components convert as follows:
Other properties or components MAY be converted to the "iCalComponent" property of the Event object.
VEVENT components with different UID property values in the same iCalendar object convert to different entries in the Group. They sort in the same order as in the VCALENDAR component.
The following example illustrates how to convert the VEVENT component:

figure.name: Converting the VEVENT component
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VCALENDAR BEGIN:VEVENT UID:DE935D01-3DF7-4201-B61A-D77D05C8B21A DTSTART:20060102T030405Z ... END:VEVENT BEGIN:VEVENT UID:60BE3D6E-6383-473A-BCF1-3C43EA1FA571 ... END:VEVENT END:VCALENDAR

section.name: VLOCATION
section.t: The VLOCATION component converts to a Location object. Its properties convert as follows:
Other properties or components MAY be converted to the "iCalComponent" property of the Location object. This includes mandatory properties such as UID.
The following example illustrates how to convert the VLOCATION component:

figure.name: Converting the VLOCATION component
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VLOCATION UID:4954DC22-5BD6-4E98-844D-0302982F54AC NAME:The venue STRUCTURED-DATA;VALUE=URI: http://dir.example.com/venues/big-hall.vcf END:VLOCATION

section.name: VTODO
section.t: The VTODO component converts to a Task object. Its properties convert as follows:
Its components convert as follows:
Other properties or components MAY be converted to the "iCalComponent" property of the Task object.
VTODO components with different UID property values in the same iCalendar object convert to different entries in the Group. They sort in the same order as in the VCALENDAR component.
The following example illustrates how to convert the VTODO component:

figure.name: Converting the VTODO component

section.name: ACKNOWLEDGED
section.t: The ACKNOWLEDGED property in a VALARM component converts to the "acknowledged" property of the Alert object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the ACKNOWLEDGED property:

figure.name: Converting the ACKNOWLEDGED property

section.name: ACTION
section.t: The ACTION property in a VALARM component converts to the "action" property of the Alert object.
Its values convert as follows:
An ACTION property with value AUDIO or any other not listed in does not convert to the "action" property. Instead, the property converts to the iCalComponent/properties property of the Alert.
The following examples illustrate how to convert the ACTION property:

figure.name: Converting the ACTION property for value DISPLAY
Converting the ACTION property for value AUDIO

section.name: ATTACH
section.t: The ATTACH property in a VEVENT, VTODO, PARTICIPANT, VLOCATION, or VCALENDAR component converts to a Link object. The converted object is set in the "links" property of the Event, Task, Participant, Location, or Group object.

The property value converts to the "href" property of the Link object. A value of type URI converts as-is. A value of type BINARY converts to a URI in the "data" URL scheme (. If the FMTTYPE parameter is set on the ATTACH property, then the parameter value MUST be set in the "mediatype" part of the data URL.
The ATTACH property parameters convert as follows:
Remarks:

ul.li: The LINKREL parameter value is defined to be either an URI or an "iana-token". Only parameter values of form "iana-token" convert to the "rel" property of the Link object. The values convert to lowercase.

section.t: The following examples illustrate how to convert the ATTACH property:

figure.name: Converting the ATTACH property with URI value
Converting the ATTACH property with BINARY value

section.name: ATTENDEE
section.t: The ATTENDEE property in a VEVENT or VTODO component converts to a Participant object. The converted object is set in the "participants" property of the Event or Task object. The property value converts to the calendarAddress property of the Participant object.

An ATTENDEE property and a PARTICIPANT component in the same iCalendar component convert to the same Participant object, if their converted calendarAddress property values are equal. How to deal with conflicting values is implementation-specific.
The ATTENDEE property parameters convert as follows:
If no ROLE parameter is set, then the "attendee" role in the "roles" property MUST be set.

The PARTSTAT of an ATTENDEE property in a VTODO component converts not only to the "participationStatus" property of the Participant object, but also to its progress property if the PARTSTAT parameter value is specific for VTODO components:

table.name: Converting the PARTSTAT parameter in a VTODO component to Participant properties

section.t: The following examples illustrate how to convert the ATTENDEE property:

figure.name: Converting the ATTENDEE property
Converting the ATTENDEE property and PARTICIPANT component
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:PARTICIPANT CALENDAR-ADDRESS:mailto:foo@example.com DESCRIPTION:some description ... END:PARTICIPANT ATTENDEE;RSVP=TRUE;PARTSTAT=TENTATIVE:mailto:foo@example.com ORGANIZER:mailto:organizer@example.com

figure.name: Converting the ATTENDEE property with a VTODO-specific participation status

section.name: CALENDAR-ADDRESS
section.t: The CALENDAR-ADDRESS property in a PARTICIPANT component converts to the "calendarAddress" property of the Participant object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the CALENDAR-ADDRESS property:

figure.name: Converting the CALENDAR-ADDRESS property

section.name: CATEGORIES
section.t: The CATEGORIES property in a VEVENT, VTODO, or VCALENDAR component converts to the "keywords" property of the Event, Task, or Group object.

The list of category values converts to a set of keywords. The values convert case-sensitively. All CATEGORIES properties in the same iCalendar component convert to the "keywords" property in the JSCalendar object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the CATEGORIES property:

figure.name: Converting the CATEGORIES property

section.name: CLASS
section.t: The CLASS property in a VEVENT or VTODO component converts to the "privacy" property of the Event or Task object.
Its values convert as follows:
Any other value does not convert to the "class" property. Instead, the property converts to the iCalComponent/properties property of the JSCalendar object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the CLASS property:

figure.name: Converting the CLASS property

section.name: COLOR
section.t: The COLOR property in a VEVENT, VTODO, or VCALENDAR component converts to the "color" property of the Event, Task, or Group object.
Its value converts verbatim.
The following examples illustrate how to convert the COLOR property:

figure.name: Converting the COLOR property with color name
Converting the COLOR property with numeric value

section.name: CONCEPT
section.t: The CONCEPT property in a VEVENT, VTODO, or VCALENDAR component converts to the "categories" property of the Event, Task, or Group object.
The list of URI values converts to a set of URIs. Multiple occurrences of the CONCEPT property in the same iCalendar component convert to the same categories property in the JSCalendar object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the CONCEPT property:

figure.name: Converting the CONCEPT property

section.name: CONFERENCE
section.t: The CONFERENCE property in a VEVENT or VTODO component converts to a VirtualLocation object. The converted object is set in the "virtualLocations" property of the Event or Task object. The property value converts to the "uri" property of the VirtualLocation object.
The CONFERENCE property and a VCONFERENCE component convert to the same VirtualLocation, if the CONFERENCE property value matches the URI property value of the VCONFERENCE component. Also see .
Its parameters convert as follows:
The following example illustrates how to convert the CONFERENCE property:

figure.name: Converting the CONFERENCE property

section.name: COORDINATES
section.t: The COORDINATES property in a VLOCATION component converts to the "coordinates" property of the Location object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the COORDINATES property:

figure.name: Converting the COORDINATES property

section.name: CREATED
section.t: The CREATED property in a VEVENT, VTODO, or VCALENDAR component converts to the "created" property of the Event, Task, or Group object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the CREATED property:

figure.name: Converting the CREATED property

section.name: DESCRIPTION
section.t: The DESCRIPTION property in a VEVENT, VTODO, VCALENDAR, VLOCATION, or PARTICIPANT component converts to the "description" property of the Event, Task, Group, Location, Link, or Participant object, unless its DERIVED parameter value is TRUE.

If the DERIVED parameter value is TRUE, then the property does not convert to the "description" property. Instead, a non-derived STYLED-DESCRIPTION property is expected to contain the description. Implementations MAY preserve the property in the "iCalComponent" property.

If the LANGUAGE parameter is set and the DESCRIPTION property is set in a VEVENT or VTODO component, then the parameter value converts to the "locale" property of the Event or Task object, unless the SUMMARY property in the same component has the LANGUAGE parameter set.

If the LANGUAGE parameter is set and the DESCRIPTION property is set in a VCALENDAR component, then the parameter value converts to the "locale" property of the Group object, unless the NAME property in the same component has the LANGUAGE parameter set.
The following example illustrates how to convert the DESCRIPTION property:

figure.name: Converting the DESCRIPTION property
figure.sourcecode: DESCRIPTION:Their pancakes are delicious\; they are fluffy and sweet.
"description": "Their pancakes are delicious; they are fluffy and sweet."

section.name: DTEND
section.t: The DTEND property in a VEVENT component converts to the "duration" property of the Event object.
The duration is the timespan between the points in time of the DTSTART and DTEND property values when converted to UTC time.
If the timezone identifier of the DTEND property differs from that of the DTSTART property, then it converts to the "endTimeZone" property of the Event.

Implementations MAY preserve the fact that the duration got determined by the DTEND property. How to do this depends on the timezone identifiers of the DTSTART and DTEND properties: If the time zone identifiers are not equal, then the presence of the "endTimeZone" property implies that it converted from the DTEND property. If the time zone identifiers are equal, then implementations MAY set the "iCalComponent" property in the Event object and there add an entry for the path "duration" in the "convertedProperties" property. The value MUST be an ICalProperty object with the "name" property set to "dtend".
The following examples illustrate how to convert the DTEND property:

figure.name: Converting the DTEND property with different timezone
Converting the DTEND property with same timezone
Converting the DTEND property with DATE value type

section.name: DTSTAMP
section.t: The DTSTAMP property in a VEVENT or VTODO component converts to the "updated" property of the Event or Task object.
The following examples illustrate how to convert the DTSTAMP property:

figure.name: Converting the DTSTAMP property in a VEVENT component
Converting the DTSTAMP property in a PARTICIPANT component

section.name: DTSTART
section.t: The DTSTART property in a VEVENT or VTODO component converts to the "start" property of the Event or Task object.
See how to convert DATE and DATE-TIME values.

For VEVENT and VTODO components, the timezone identifier of the DTSTART property converts to the "timeZone" property of the Event or Task object. In addition, if the value type of the DTSTART property is DATE, then the value of the "showWithoutTime" property is "true".
The following examples illustrate how to convert the DTSTART property for the VEVENT and VTODO components.

figure.name: Converting the DTSTART property with TZID parameter
Converting the DTSTART property with UTC time
Converting the DTSTART property with floating time
Converting the DTSTART property with value type DATE

section.name: DUE
section.t: The DUE property in a VTODO component converts to the "due" property of the Task object.
See how to convert DATE and DATE-TIME values.

If the VTODO component does not contain a DTSTART property, then the timezone identifier of the DUE property converts to the "timeZone" property of the Task object. If it contains both the DUE and DTSTART properties and the timezone identifier of the DUE property differs from that of the DTSTART property, then the "due" date-time property value MUST be relative to the time zone of DTSTART.
If the value type of the DUE property is DATE, then the value of the "showWithoutTime" property is "true".
The following examples illustrate how to convert the DUE property:

figure.name: Converting the DUE property with TZID parameter
Converting the DUE property with UTC time
Converting the DUE property with floating time
Converting the DUE property with value type DATE
Converting the DUE property with value type DATE in combination with DTSTART

section.name: DURATION
section.t: The DURATION property in a VEVENT or VTODO component converts to the "duration" property of the Event or Task object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the DURATION property:

figure.name: Converting the DURATION

section.name: ESTIMATED-DURATION
section.t: The ESTIMATED-DURATION property in a VTODO component converts to the "estimatedDuration" property of the Task object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the ESTIMATED-DURATION property:

figure.name: Converting the ESTIMATED-DURATION

section.name: EXDATE
section.t: The EXDATE property in a VEVENT or VTODO component converts to a PatchObject value. The converted object is set in the "recurrenceOverrides" property of the Event or Task object.

The property value converts to the key in the "recurrenceOverrides" property value. See how to convert DATE and DATE-TIME values. The date-time MUST be relative to the timezone identified by the "timeZone" property of the Event or Task. The PatchObject value MUST set the "excluded" member to "true" and MUST NOT set any other property.
The following example illustrates how to convert the EXDATE property:

figure.name: Converting the EXDATE property

section.name: GEO
section.t: A GEO property with the DERIVED parameter value "TRUE" does not convert to JSCalendar. For non-derived GEO properties, the following rules apply:

The GEO property in a VEVENT or VTODO component converts to a Location object. If the VEVENT or VTODO component also contains the LOCATION property, then the GEO and LOCATION properties convert to the same Location object. The converted object is set in the "locations" property of the Event or Task object.
The GEO property in a PARTICIPANT component converts to a Location object. The converted object is set in the "locations" property of the Participant object.
The GEO property in a VLOCATION component converts to the "coordinates" property of the Location object.

The pair of FLOAT values converts to a URI with the "geo" scheme. The first FLOAT value converts to the "coord-a" part of the URI, the second FLOAT value to the "coord-b" part. A preceding plus sign (+) of the FLOAT value MUST be omitted, a preceding minus sign (-) MUST be preserved. The optional "coord-c" part of the URI MUST be omitted.
Implementations MAY preserve the fact that the Location "coordinates" property converted from a GEO property. How to do so depends on how the GEO property converted to a Location object:

ul.li: If the GEO property converted from a VLOCATION component, then implementations MAY add a path to the "coordinates" property in the "iCalComponent/convertedProperties" property of the Location object.

Otherwise, implementations MAY set the "iCalProperty" property of the Location object. Alternatively they MAY add a "iCalComponent" property to the object that contains this Location object in its "locations" property, and point to the "coordinates" property in the "convertedProperties" property.

section.t: The following examples illustrate how to convert the GEO property:

figure.name: Converting the GEO property in a VEVENT
Converting the GEO and LOCATION properties in a VEVENT
Converting the GEO property in a VLOCATION

section.name: IMAGE
section.t: The IMAGE property in a VEVENT, VTODO, VLOCATION, PARTICIPANT, or VCALENDAR component converts to a Link object. The converted object is set in the "links" property of the Event, Task, Location, Participant, or Group object.

The property value converts to the "href" property of the Link object. A value of type URI converts as-is. See how to convert a BINARY value. If the DISPLAY parameter is set, then the "rel" property of the Link object MUST be set to "icon".
Its parameters convert as follows:
The following example illustrates how to convert the IMAGE property:

figure.name: Converting the IMAGE property

section.name: LAST-MODIFIED
section.t: The LAST-MODIFIED property in a VCALENDAR component converts to the "updated" property of the Group object.

The LAST-MODIFIED property in a VEVENT or VTODO component does not convert to the "updated" property of the Event or Task object. Implementations MAY instead preserve the LAST-MODIFIED property in the "iCalComponent" property.
The following example illustrates how to convert the LAST-MODIFIED property:

figure.name: Converting the IMAGE property

section.name: LINK
section.t: A LINK property with value type URI in a VEVENT, VTODO, PARTICIPANT, VLOCATION, or VCALENDAR component converts to a Link object. The converted object is set in the "links" property of the Event, Task, Participant, Location, or Group object.
The property value converts to the "href" property of the Link object.
The LINK property parameters convert as follows:
Remarks:

ul.li: The LINKREL parameter value is defined to be either an URI or an "iana-token". Only parameter values of form "iana-token" convert to the "rel" property of the Link object. The values convert to lowercase.

section.t: A LINK property with any other value type does not convert to a standard JSCalendar element. Implementations MAY convert it to the "iCalComponent" property.
The following example illustrates how to convert the LINK property:

figure.name: Converting the LINK property

section.name: LOCATION
section.t: The LOCATION property in a VEVENT or VTODO component converts to a Location object, unless its DERIVED parameter value is TRUE. The converted object is set in the "locations" property of the Event or Task. The property value converts to the "title" property of the Location object. If the DERIVED parameter value is TRUE, then the property does not convert to a Location object. Instead, a VLOCATION component is expected to convert to a Location object.

If the calendar component contains multiple VLOCATION components, then the LOCATION property also converts to the "mainLocationId" property of the Event or Task object. If the LOCATION property is not derived, then the identifier of its Location object is set in the "mainLocationId". If instead the LOCATION property is derived and its property value matches the NAME property value of a VLOCATION component, then the "mainLocationId" property value matches the identifier of the Location object to which that VLOCATION component converts to.
The following example illustrates how to convert the LOCATION property:

figure.name: Converting the LOCATION property

section.t: The following example illustrates how to convert the LOCATION property and multiple VLOCATION components:

figure.name: Converting the LOCATION property and multiple VLOCATION components
figure.sourcecode: LOCATION;DERIVED=TRUE:Fred's Bar BEGIN:VLOCATION NAME:Fred's Bar LOCATION-TYPE:bar ... END:VLOCATION BEGIN:VLOCATION NAME:XYZ Parking LOCATION-TYPE:parking GEO:40.71427;-74.00597 ... END:VLOCATION

section.name: LOCATION-TYPE
section.t: The LOCATION-TYPE property in a VLOCATION component converts to the "locationTypes" property of the Location object.

The list of location type values converts to a set of location types. The values convert case-sensitively. All LOCATION-TYPE properties in the same VLOCATION convert to the "locationTypes" property in the Location object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the LOCATION-TYPE property:

figure.name: Converting the LOCATION property

section.name: METHOD
section.t: The METHOD property in a VCALENDAR component converts to the "method" property of all Event or Task objects that are listed in the Group object's entries property.
The property value converts in lowercase.
The following example illustrates how to convert the METHOD property:

figure.name: Converting the METHOD property

section.name: NAME
section.t: The NAME property in a VLOCATION component converts to the "name" property of the Location or Participant object.

The NAME property in a VCALENDAR component converts to the "title" property of the Group object. If the LANGUAGE parameter is set, then the parameter value converts to the "locale" property of the same object.
The following examples illustrate how to convert the NAME property:

figure.name: Converting the NAME property in a VCALENDAR component
Converting the NAME property in the VLOCATION component

section.name: ORGANIZER
section.t: The ORGANIZER property in a VEVENT or VTODO component converts to the "organizerCalendarAddress" property of the Event or Task object and to a Participant object in the "participants" property. The ORGANIZER property value converts to the "calendarAddress" property of the Participant, the "owner" role is set in Participant "roles" property.

An ORGANIZER property, an ATTENDEE property, and a PARTICIPANT component in the same iCalendar component all convert to the same Participant object, if their converted calendarAddress property values are equal. How to deal with conflicting property values is implementation-specific.
The ORGANIZER property parameters convert as follows:
The following examples illustrate how to convert the ORGANIZER property:

figure.name: Converting an ORGANIZER property
Converting an ORGANIZER and ATTENDEE property

section.name: PERCENT-COMPLETE
section.t: The PERCENT-COMPLETE property in a VTODO component converts to the "percentComplete" property of the Task object.

A Task object which has the "method" property set might represent an iTIP reply of one of the participants in the object. In this case the value of the "percentComplete" property in the Task also converts to the percentComplete of that Participant object, which represents the participant from which the iTIP reply originated.
The PERCENT-COMPLETE property in a PARTICIPANT component converts to the "percentComplete" property of the Participant object.
The following examples illustrate how to convert the PERCENT-COMPLETE property:

figure.name: Converting the PERCENT-COMPLETE property in a VEVENT component
Converting the PERCENT-COMPLETE property in a PARTICIPANT component

section.name: PRIORITY
section.t: The PRIORITY property in a VEVENT or VTODO component converts to the "priority" property of the Event or Task object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the PRIORITY property:

figure.name: Converting the PRIORITY property

section.name: PRODID
section.t: The PRODID property in a VCALENDAR component converts to the "prodId" property of the Group object, and to the "prodId" property of all Event or Task objects that are listed in the Group object's entries property.
The property value converts verbatim.
The following example illustrates how to convert the PRODID property:

figure.name: Converting the PRODID property

section.name: RDATE
section.t: A RDATE property with value type DATE or DATE-TIME in a VEVENT or VTODO component converts to a PatchObject value. The converted object is set in the "recurrenceOverrides" property of the Event or Task object.

The property value converts to the key in the "recurrenceOverrides" property value. See how to convert DATE and DATE-TIME values. The date-time MUST be relative to the timezone identified by the "timeZone" property of the Event or Task object. The PatchObject value MUST be an empty JSON object.
A RDATE property with value type PERIOD does not convert to a standard JSCalendar element. Implementations MAY convert it to the "iCalComponent" property of the Event or Task object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the RDATE property:

figure.name: Converting the RDATE property

section.name: RECURRENCE-ID
section.t: The RECURRENCE-ID property in a VEVENT or VTODO component converts to the "recurrenceId" property of the Event or Task object. The timezone identifier of the RECURRENCE-ID property converts to the "recurrenceIdTimeZone" property.
See how to convert DATE and DATE-TIME values.
The RANGE parameter does not convert to a standard JSCalendar element. Implementations MAY preserve it in the iCalComponent property.
See for further requirements and examples.

section.name: RELATED-TO
section.t: The RELATED-TO property in a VEVENT, VTODO, or VALARM component converts to a Relation object. The converted object is set in the "relatedTo" property of the Event or Task object, or the Alert object.

The property value in a VEVENT or VTODO converts as-is to the id of the Relation object in the "relatedTo" property. The property value in a VALARM converts to the same value as the id of that Alert object, which represents the VALARM component having that property value set in the UID property. Any RELTYPE parameters convert to the "relations" property in that Relation object. The parameter values convert in lowercase.
The following examples illustrate how to convert the RELATED-TO property:

figure.name: Converting the RELATED-TO property in a VEVENT
Converting the RELATED-TO property in a VALARM
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VEVENT ... BEGIN:VALARM UID:8297C37D-BA2D-4476-91AE-C1EAA364F8E1 JSID:alert1 TRIGGER:-PT15M DESCRIPTION:Event reminder ACTION:DISPLAY ACKNOWLEDGED:20210302T151514Z END:VALARM ... BEGIN:VALARM UID:DE7B5C34-83FF-47FE-BE9E-FF41AE6DD097 JSID:alert2 TRIGGER;VALUE=DATE-TIME:20210302T152000Z RELATED-TO;RELTYPE=SNOOZE:8297C37D-BA2D-4476-91AE-C1EAA364F8E1 DESCRIPTION:Event reminder ACTION:DISPLAY END:VALARM ...

section.name: RRULE
section.t: The RRULE property in a VEVENT or VTODO component converts to a RecurrenceRule object. The converted object is set in the "recurrenceRule" property of the Event or Task object.
The RECUR value type converts to a RecurrenceRule object as follows:

table.name: Converting the RECUR value type to a RecurrenceRule object

section.t: The string values of the FREQ, WKST, RSCALE convert to lowercase. The UNTIL part in a VEVENT or VTODO converts to a LocalDateTime value relative to the timezone of the Event or Task object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the RRULE property:

figure.name: Example for converting the RRULE property

section.name: SEQUENCE
section.t: The SEQUENCE property in a VEVENT or VTODO component converts to the "sequence" property of the Event or Task object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the SEQUENCE property:

figure.name: Example for converting the SEQUENCE property

section.name: STATUS
section.t:
The STATUS property in a VEVENT component converts to the "status" property of the Event object.
The STATUS property in a VTODO component converts to the "progress" property of the Task object.
The property value converts in lowercase.
The following examples illustrate how to convert the STATUS property:

figure.name: Example for converting the STATUS property in a VEVENT component
Example for converting the STATUS property in a VTODO component

section.name: SOURCE
section.t: The SOURCE property in a VCALENDAR component converts to the "source" property of the Group object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the SOURCE property:

figure.name: Example for converting the SOURCE property

section.name: STYLED-DESCRIPTION
section.t: The STYLED-DESCRIPTION property in a PARTICIPANT, VLOCATION, VEVENT or VTODO component converts to the "description" property of the Participant, Location, Event or Task object under the following conditions:

ul.li: The property value type MUST be TEXT.
The FMTTYPE parameter either MUST NOT be set, or its value MUST be a media type with top-level type "text".
Its DERIVED parameter value MUST NOT be TRUE. If the value is TRUE, then another property in the same component is expected to contain the description.

section.t: If these conditions are not met, implementations MAY preserve the property in the "iCalComponent" property.

If the LANGUAGE parameter is set and the STYLED-DESCRIPTION property is set in a VEVENT or VTODO component, then the parameter value converts to the "locale" property of the Event or Task object, unless the SUMMARY or DESCRIPTION properties in the same component have the LANGUAGE parameter set.
Its parameters convert as follows:
The following example illustrates how to convert the STYLED-DESCRIPTION property:

figure.name: Converting the STYLED-DESCRIPTION property

section.name: SUMMARY
section.t: The SUMMARY property in a VEVENT or VTODO component converts to the "title" property of the Event or Task object. If the LANGUAGE parameter is set, then the parameter value converts to the "locale" property of the same object.
The SUMMARY property in a PARTICIPANT component converts to the "name" property.
The following examples illustrate how to convert the SUMMARY property:

figure.name: Converting the SUMMARY property in a VEVENT
Converting the SUMMARY property with LANGUAGE parameter in a VEVENT
Converting the SUMMARY property in a PARTICIPANT

section.name: TRANSP
section.t: The TRANSP property in a VEVENT or VTODO component converts to the "freeBusyStatus" property of the Event or Task object.
Its values convert as follows:
The following example illustrates how to convert the TRANSP property:

figure.name: Converting the TRANSP property

section.name: TRIGGER
section.t: The TRIGGER property in a VALARM component converts to either an AbsoluteTrigger or OffsetTrigger object. The converted object is set in the "trigger" property of the Alert object.

A property of value type DURATION converts an OffsetTrigger object. The property value converts to its offset property. A value of type DATE-TIME converts to an AbsoluteTrigger object. The property value converts to its when property.
Its parameters convert as follows:
The following examples illustrate how to convert the TRIGGER property:

figure.name: Converting the TRIGGER property to an OffsetTrigger
Converting the TRIGGER property to an AbsoluteTrigger

section.name: UID
section.t: The UID property in a VEVENT, VTODO, or VCALENDAR component converts to the "uid" property of the Event, Task, or Group object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the UID property:

figure.name: Converting the UID property

section.name: Alert
section.t: The Alert object converts to a VALARM component. Its properties convert as follows:
Remarks:

li.t: The value of the RELATED-TO property is the UID property value of that VALARM component, to which the related Alert object converts to. Consequently, the UID property for such a VALARM MUST be set, otherwise the UID property MAY be set.

section.t: Other properties MAY be converted to JSPROP properties in the VALARM component.

section.name: Event and Task
section.t: The Event object converts to a VEVENT component, the Task object converts to a VTODO component.

The following table defines how to convert properties that are common to both the Event and Task object types. and later in this section define how to convert properties specific to either Event or Task objects.

table.name: Properties of the Event and Task object

tr.td: LANGUAGE (parameter) of either SUMMARY, or DESCRIPTION, or STYLED-DESCRIPTION (in order of preference)
RDATE, EXDATE or recurrence override component

section.t: Remarks:

li.t: The descriptionContentType property value determines if the "description" property converts to the DESCRIPTION or STYLED-DESCRIPTION property. A description of content type "text/plain" converts to the DESCRIPTION property. Any other description converts to the STYLED-DESCRIPTION property, in which case a plain text version of the rich-text description MAY be set additionally in the DESCRIPTION property, having its DERIVED parameter set to "TRUE". How to derive plain text from rich-text is implementation-specific.

The entries in the "recurrenceOverrides" property convert depending on the contents of the PatchObject value. A PatchObject that sets the "excluded" member to "true" converts to an EXDATE property for the date-time of that recurrence instance. An empty PatchObject converts to an RDATE property. Any other PatchObject converts to a recurrence override component in the embedding VCALENDAR component.

section.t: Properties specific to the Event object type convert to iCalendar properties as follows:
Properties specific to the Task object type convert to iCalendar properties as follows:
Other properties MAY be converted to JSPROP properties in the VEVENT or VTODO component.

section.name: Group
section.t: The Group object converts to a VCALENDAR component. Its properties convert as follows:

td.t: Event and Task object, and remarks below

tr.td: LANGUAGE (parameter) of either NAME, or DESCRIPTION (in order of preference)

section.t: Remarks:

li.t: The prodId property value of the Group object is expected to be equal to the "prodId" property value of all the Group entries. They all convert to the same, single PRODID property in the VCALENDAR component. How to convert unequal prodId property values is implementation-specific.
The method property value in all the Group entries is expected to be equal. How to convert entries with unequal method property values is implementation-specific.

section.t: Other properties MAY be converted to JSPROP properties in the VCALENDAR component.

section.name: Link
section.t: The Link object converts either an ATTACH property or an IMAGE property. Which iCalendar property to choose is implementation-specific. As a guideline:

ul.li: Choose the iCalendar property name indicated in the Link object's iCalProperty property, if set.
Choose IMAGE, if the "rel" property value is "icon".
Choose LINK, if the "rel" property is set to any value other than "icon".
Choose ATTACH otherwise.

section.t: The href property converts to the "iCalendar" property value. The other Link properties convert as follows:
Remarks:

ul.li: The LINKREL parameter MUST be omitted if the Link object converts to an IMAGE property and the "rel" property value is "icon".

section.t: Other properties MAY be converted to JSPROP properties in the same component to which the Link object converts to as a property.

section.name: Location
section.t: The Location object converts to either a LOCATION, GEO, or DTEND property, or it converts to a VLOCATION component. Which iCalendar element to choose is implementation-specific. As a guideline:

ul.li: If the "iCalProperty" or "iCalComponent" property on the Location object is set, or the parent JSCalendar object contains an entry for that Location in the "convertedProperties" property of its "iCalComponent" property, then convert the object back to the named iCalendar element.

Choose LOCATION if the key of the Location object in the "locations" property matches the "mainLocationId" property, or if the "name" property is set and the iCalendar component does not already contain a LOCATION property. The "name" property converts to the LOCATION property value.
Choose the VLOCATION component otherwise.

section.t: Implementations MAY convert one of the Location objects to both a VLOCATION component and the LOCATION and GEO properties of the component that contains the VLOCATION component. In this case, the DERIVED parameter MUST be set on the LOCATION and GEO properties with value "TRUE".
The properties convert to a VLOCATION component as follows:
Other properties MAY be converted to JSPROP properties in the VLOCATION component, or the component which the Location converts to as a property.

section.name: Participant
section.t: The Participant object converts to both an ATTENDEE property and a PARTICIPANT component:

li.t: It converts to an ATTENDEE property if the calendarAddress property is set.

It converts to a PARTICIPANT component if any of the Participant properties in are set. If the Participant object also converts to an ATTENDEE property, then the CALENDAR-ADDRESS property value of the PARTICIPANT component MUST match the ATTENDEE property value.

section.t: The following Participant properties convert to the ATTENDEE property. How to convert these properties if the Participant does not convert to an ATTENDEE is implementation-specific.

table.name: Properties of the Participant object that convert to the ATTENDEE property

section.t: Remarks:

li.t: The "attendee" role does not convert to the ROLE parameter: it either is implied if the Participant object converts to an ATTENDEE, otherwise implementations MAY preserve it using the JSPROP property. The "owner" role does not convert to any standard iCalendar element: it either is implied if the property value of the ATTENDEE is equal to the value of the ORGANIZER property in the same component, otherwise implementations MAY preserve it using the JSPROP property.
The progress property converts to the PARTSTAT parameter as outlined in .

section.t: The following Participant properties convert to the PARTICIPANT component:

table.name: Properties of the Participant object that convert to the PARTICIPANT component

section.t: Other properties MAY be converted to JSPROP properties in the PARTICIPANT component, or the component which the Participant converts to as a property.

section.name: VirtualLocation
section.t: The VirtualLocation object converts to a CONFERENCE property. If the "description" property is set, then it also converts to a VCONFERENCE component.

The "uri" property converts to the CONFERENCE property value. If the VirtualLocation object converts to a VCONFERENCE component, then the "uri" property also converts to the URI property of the VCONFERENCE component.
The following properties convert to parameters of the CONFERENCE property:
The following properties convert to properties of the VCONFERENCE component:
Other properties MAY be converted to JSPROP properties of the VCONFERENCE component.

dl.dd: JSID
This property preserves the identifier of a JSCalendar object value in iCalendar.
TEXT; also see "Format Definition" below for value restrictions.
IANA and non-standard property parameters can be specified on this property.
This property can be specified at most once in any calendar component.

dd.t: This property specifies the JSON object key of the JSCalendar object to which an iCalendar component converts to. For example, this property set in a VALARM component within a VEVENT component defines the key of the Alert object value in the Event object's "alerts" property (see ).
The value of the JSID property MUST be a valid object key according to the definition of the JSCalendar property to which the component converts to.
This property is defined by the following notation:
The following example illustrates how to convert the JSID property set in a VALARM component.

figure.name: Converting the JSID property of a VALARM component

dl.dd: JSPROP
This property represents a JSCalendar property in iCalendar.
TEXT; also see "Format Definition" below for value restrictions.
The JSPTR parameter MUST be specified on this property. Other IANA and non-standard property parameters can be specified on this property.
This property can be specified multiple times in any calendar component.

dd.t: This property converts an arbitrary JSCalendar property from and to iCalendar. The iCalendar property value is the JSON-encoded value of the JSCalendar property, represented as a TEXT value. The JSON value MUST NOT be the null value, and it SHOULD NOT contain insignificant whitespace as defined in . The value of the JSPTR parameter points to the JSCalendar property within the JSCalendar object.

The root of the JSON pointer is always the JSCalendar object to which the calendar component converts to, even if the JSON pointer starts with the SOLIDUS (U+002F) character. The pointer MUST NOT reference into an array.

All JSPROP properties in a calendar component together form a PatchObject: the JSPTR parameter of a JSPROP property corresponds to a key in the PatchObject, the property value corresponds to the JSON value for that key. When converting from iCalendar to JSCalendar, the PatchObject MUST only be applied after all other iCalendar elements of the component have been converted. Only new properties are allowed to be set, a JSON pointer in the PatchObject that points to an existing property MUST be ignored.
This property is defined by the following notation:
The following example illustrates how to convert a JSPROP property with a JSON boolean value

figure.name: Converting the JSPROP property with a JSON boolean value

dd.t: The following example illustrates how to convert a JSPROP property with a JSON object value

figure.name: Converting the JSPROP property with a JSON object value

dd.t: The following example illustrates how to convert a JSPROP property that points to a property within a JSCalendar Alert. The JSON pointer in the JSPTR parameter is relative to the Alert object.

figure.name: Converting the JSPROP property within a VALARM component

dd.t: The following example illustrates how to convert a JSPROP property that points to a property within a JSCalendar Link. The JSON pointer in the JSPTR parameter is relative to the Event object because the Link object converts to an iCalendar property. The JSID parameter on the ATTACH property ensures that the JSON path remains valid during conversion.

figure.name: Converting the JSPROP property within a VALARM component

dl.dd: JSID

dd.t: This parameter specifies the JSON object key of the JSCalendar object to which an iCalendar property converts to. For example, this parameter set on an ATTACH property within a VEVENT component defines the key of the Link object value in the Event object's "links" property (see below for an example).

The value of the JSID parameter MUST be a valid key according to the definition of the JSCalendar property to which the property that this parameter is set on converts to. Typically, this requires the value to be a valid Id.

figure.name: Converting the JSID parameter on an ATTACH property

dl.dd: JSPTR
This parameter is specified on a JSPROP property. Its value is a JSON pointer that points to a JSCalendar property.

dd.t: This parameter has a single value that MUST be a valid JSON pointer as defined in . The value MUST be quoted to preserve its case-sensitivity and it MUST NOT contain the DQUOTE character. See for how to format parameter values.
For further examples, see .

section.name: iCalComponent

dl.dd: iCalComponent
Any JSCalendar object
ICalComponent (optional)

dd.t: This contains information about an iCalendar component that got converted to JSCalendar. It allows for preserving the name of the iCalendar component and some or all of its properties and subcomponents.
An ICalComponent object has the following properties:

dl.dd: This specifies the type of this object. This MUST be ICalComponent.
This is the name of the iCalendar component in lowercase.
This contains subcomponents of the iCalendar component which did not convert to standard JSCalendar elements. The value MUST be a list of iCalendar components formatted in jCal as defined in .

dd.t: This contains conversion-related information about the component's properties that got partially or fully converted to JSCalendar. Each key defines the path to a property of the JSCalendar object on which the "iCalComponent" property is set on. The value for each key contains information about the "iCalendar" property which converted to the "object" property located at that key (see ).

The key MUST be a valid key of a PatchObject as defined in . The key MUST NOT point into a nested property, unless there is no way to otherwise preserve the "iCalendar" property elements. For example, if a VEVENT contains an ATTENDEE property, then any iCalendar information about the ATTENDEE property MUST be set in the "iCalProperty" property of the converted Participant object (see ). In contrast, information about a RDATE property contained in a VEVENT would be located by a key pointing into the recurrenceOverrides property of the Event object (see ).

dl.dd: This contains properties of the iCalendar component which did not convert to standard JSCalendar elements. The value MUST be a list of iCalendar properties formatted in jCal as defined in .

section.t: The example in describes how to convert unknown iCalendar elements to the "iCalComponent" property. The "X-FOO" parameter set on the SUMMARY property illustrates how to preserve an unknown iCalendar parameter on a property that does convert to a standard JSCalendar element. The "X-BAR" property and "X-BAZ" component illustrate how to convert entirely unknown iCalendar elements.

figure.name: Converting unknown iCalendar elements to the iCalComponent property
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VEVENT SUMMARY;X-FOO=bar:test ... X-BAR:bam ... BEGIN:X-BAZ UID:507A08F9-81D8-4D16-9480-D6D75E977943 END:X-BAZ ...

section.name: iCalProperty

dl.dd: iCalProperty
Any JSCalendar object
ICalProperty (optional)

dd.t: This contains conversion-related information about an iCalendar property that got partially or fully converted to a JSCalendar object. It allows for preserving the name of the "iCalendar" property and some or all of its parameters.
An ICalProperty object has the following properties:

dl.dd: This specifies the type of this object. This MUST be ICalProperty.
This is the name of the "iCalendar" property in lowercase.
This is the name of the "iCalendar" property value type in lowercase.
This contains parameters of the "iCalendar" property. The value MUST comply with iCalendar parameters formatted in jCal as defined in .

section.t: The example in describes how to convert an unknown parameter to the "iCalProperty" property. The ATTACH property converts to a Link object. To preserve the unknown "X-FOO" parameter, the "iCalProperty" property is set on the Link object.

figure.name: Converting the ATTACH property with an unknown parameter

front.title: JSCalendar: A JSON Representation of Calendar Data

section.name: Discrepancies between iCalendar and JSCalendar
section.t: This section highlights iCalendar and JSCalendar elements for which no conversion rule to a standard element is defined in this document. This is informational and only complete at the time of publication of this document.

Implementations MAY choose to convert the following elements, for example using the properties defined in and , or they might convert them to some vendor-specific extension properties. Later RFC documents might also define new standard elements and register them at IANA, either extending this list of inconvertible elements, or rather reduce it by introducing a standard element to convert to.

section.name: Components
section.t: The following components do not convert to a standard element in JSCalendar:

section.name: Properties by Component
section.t: The following components are defined to contain the listed properties. But these properties do not convert to a standard JSCalendar element.

section.name: Subcomponents by Component
section.t: The following components are defined to contain the listed subcomponents. But these subcomponents do not convert to a standard JSCalendar element.

section.name: Properties by Value Type
section.t: The following properties convert to a standard JSCalendar element for some other value type, but they do not for the listed value types.

section.name: Parameters by Property
section.t: The following properties are defined to contain the listed parameters. But these parameters do not convert to a standard JSCalendar element.

ul.li: DISPLAY (if the parameter value contains more than one "displayval").
LINKREL (if the parameter value does not conform to the "reg-rel-type" ABNF in ).

section.name: Unsupported JSCalendar Properties
section.t: The following properties are defined for the respective object type, but they do not convert to a standard iCalendar element.
